metadata.h1: The Fascinating Science and Art of Decision-boards
metadata.description: This article recounts distilled insights from my experience of designing dashboards for several US fortune 50 firms. This piece talks about (1) Philosophy and Purpose of Decision-boards (2) Design and Development Process (3) Nurturing: Keeping it relevant in the long term and (4) Assembly line for producing dashboards at scale

all_paragraphs: This article contains distilled insights from my experience of designing decision boards (aka dashboards) for several US fortune 50 firms. Effective decision-boards are elemental in establishing control over the business at hand and augmenting the decision-making process. With a blend of heart and practical wisdom, this piece is meant to enchant you into the world of dashboarding and deliver a win if you happen to design it in your line of work.

Businesses exist to make a profit. They do so by either selling a product, service, or experience. Decision-boards help monitor the performance of a business, by visually displaying the most important metrics to assess the health of a business or an aspect of it. And helps the owner make an informed decision more quickly.

Think of a decision-board as a miniaturized abstraction of reality, where KPIs quantify a certain aspect or objective(s) of the business. These KPIs are arranged into a neat compressed view so that the business owner can quickly eyeball it and get a sense of how the business is performing.

Corporate folklore has it that the 2001 Enron Scandal catapulted the dashboard as a way for CEOs to keep shareholders placated, and also distribute accountability down the hierarchical ranks. Decision-boards have occupied a permanent place in businesses since. With the democratization of technology, where the next disruptive idea is always lurking around the corner, the need to stay competitive and relevant has only peaked. Business and product owners of today must have well-designed and robust measurement systems in place to be aware of their situational realities and observe the effect of historical business decisions.

The sophistication of metrics in a decision-board depends on the analytical maturity of the organization. Let’s take the business of a Disney World theme park business to understand variations in the metric complexity.

A well-designed decision-board eases the monitoring process at the bare minimum, and clearly calls-out Descriptive metrics (“What has happened”). For example for the Disneyland theme park, this could be the total profit that was generated last month.

While being in harmony with the target audience will allow faster iterations, we also need some construct to formalize and cycle through the iterations. Design Thinking is a popular method to enable that. The principles on which it is based originated from the best practices in engineering, architecture, and software design. We can borrowing from Design Thinking principles, to establish an execution framework for decision-board creation. The stages of Design-Development-Review can span over a weeks or months (depending on the suite of dashboards being created), to land a winning outcome.
